column1: The automotive industry in Malaysia consists of 27 vehicle producers and over 640 component manufacturers. The Malaysian automotive industry is the third largest in Southeast Asia
column2: and the 23rd largest in the world
column3: with an annual production output of over 500
column4: 000 vehicles. The automotive industry contributes 4% or RM 40 billion to Malaysia's GDP
column5: and employs a workforce of over 700
column6: 000 throughout a nationwide ecosystem.The automotive industry in Malaysia traces its origins back to the British colonial era. Ford Malaya became the first automobile assembly plant in Southeast Asia upon its establishment in Singapore in 1926. The automotive industry in post-independence Malaysia was established in 1967 to spur national industrialisation. The government offered initiatives to encourage the local assembly of vehicles and manufacturing of automobile components. In 1983
column7: the government became directly involved in the automotive industry through the establishment of national car company Proton
column8: followed by Perodua in 1993. Since the 2000s
column9: the government had sought to liberalise the domestic automotive industry through free-trade agreements
column10: privatisation and harmonisation of UN regulations.

column1: The Malaysian automotive industry is Southeast Asia's sole pioneer of indigenous car companies
column2: namely Proton and Perodua. In 2002
column3: Proton helped Malaysia become the 11th country in the world with the capability to fully design
column4: engineer and manufacture cars from the ground up. The Malaysian automotive industry also hosts several domestic-foreign joint venture companies
column5: which assemble a large variety of vehicles from imported complete knock down (CKD) kits.

column1: The automotive industry in Malaysia primarily serves domestic demand
column2: and only several thousand complete built up (CBU) vehicles are exported annually. Exports of Malaysian made parts and components have nonetheless grown significantly in the last decade
column3: contributing over RM 11 billion to Malaysia's GDP in 2016.

column1: ==== Malaya during the British colonial era ====
Malaysia had been a British colony prior to its independence in the mid-20th century. West Malaysia was originally known as Malaya
column2: and was governed separately from the would-be East Malaysian states of North Borneo and Sarawak. British colonisation of Malaya began in the late 18th century
column3: and would encompass all of Malaya by the early 20th century. British rule in Malaya was divided between the Straits Settlements (which included Singapore)
column4: the Federated Malay States and the Unfederated Malay States.

column2: the Malayan economy was largely dependent on natural rubber and tin commodity exports. Industrialisation in British Malaya was not emphasised due to the profitability and high demand for rubber and tin. Malaya was strategically located along major ocean trade routes originating from East Asia and the Indian Ocean. Trade and commerce made British Malaya the most prosperous of all the European colonies in Southeast Asia.The boom of rubber and tin exports had funded the growth of the Malayan road network over the decades. In 1911
column3: there were over 4
column4: 000 miles of road in the Straits Settlements and the Federated Malay States. By 1923
column5: it was possible to drive from Singapore to Bangkok on the Malayan north-south highway. Car ownership in Malaya had also increased ten-fold between 1910 and 1925.

column1: The earliest automobiles arrived in Malaya during the 1890s and 1900s. Western car companies from America
column2: the British Empire and Continental Europe had established a strong foothold in Malaya by the 1910s. The automobile market in colonial Malaya was relatively small
column3: and catered mainly to British expatriates and wealthy ethnic Chinese entrepreneurs in major cities such as Singapore
column4: Penang
column5: Kuala Lumpur and Ipoh.In the early 20th century
column6: American car companies collectively held the largest share of the Malayan car market. The British administration made attempts to restrict the advancement of American cars in Malaya
column7: as a means of protecting British business interests. American cars were subject to tariffs and periodical bans
column8: while cars from Britain were allowed to be sold duty-free in Malaya. However
column9: American cars were often cheaper despite the costly taxes
column10: and some companies found ways to circumvent the tax restrictions altogether.

column1: The automobile industry in British Malaya was pioneered by the Ford Motor Company. Ford sought to capitalise on existing Anglo-American ties to expand globally
column2: and Malaya was recognised for its strategic potential as a regional export base. Ford's entry into Malaya was spearheaded by Ford Canada
column3: an affiliate of Ford USA. Ford Canada was set up in 1904 to capitalise on its British colony status
column4: which allowed it to export automobiles duty-free to the various Empire colonies. Ford Canada appointed Dodge & Seymour to handle sales in Asia
column5: and the first Ford models were shipped into Malaya in 1909. Malayan Ford sales grew in the following years
column6: and Ford Canada decided to take direct control of its Malayan operations in 1926.In November 1926
column7: the Ford Motor Company of Malaya Ltd. (Ford Malaya) was incorporated in Singapore
column8: and the company set up a small garage in a two-storey shop house on Anson Road. The garage carried out wheel-fitting and touching up for Model T units between 1926 and 1929. In January 1930
column9: Ford Malaya moved operations to a warehouse in Prince Edward Road
column10: where they carried out more sophisticated semi-knock down (SKD) assembly. The new plant assembled SKD kits which were imported from Ford Canada and Ford England. Ford's market share in British Malaya peaked at 80% in 1939.

column2: Ford Malaya moved operations to their all-new assembly plant in Bukit Timah
column3: Singapore. The 1941 Ford Malaya factory became the first fully-fledged automobile assembly plant in Southeast Asia. Complete-knock down (CKD) body assembly commenced in October 1941. However
column4: World War II broke out in Malaya just two months later
column5: and Singapore fell to the invading Japanese Army in February 1942. The Ford Malaya plant became the venue where British General Percival formally surrendered to General Yamashita of Japan. During the occupation of Singapore
column6: the Japanese used the Ford plant to assemble Nissan and Toyota trucks for the military. Following Japan's surrender in 1945
column7: the British army reacquired the plant and returned it to Ford Malaya in 1946
column8: and production recommenced in April 1947.Between 1926 and 1965
column9: Ford Malaya stood as the sole automobile assembler in Singapore. Throughout its history
column10: Ford Malaya would export its produce to British Malaya (later West Malaysia)
column11: British Borneo (later East Malaysia and Brunei)
column12: Siam (later Thailand)
column13: the Dutch East Indies (later Indonesia)
column15: India and Pakistan. Ford Malaya had imported SKD and CKD kits from the United States
column18: Germany and Australia respectively. Ford Malaya produced over 150
column20: and finally closed down in 1980. The government of Singapore would later gazette the old Ford factory as a national monument in February 2006.

column2: General Motors (GM) of America had also expressed intentions to establish a regional hub in British Malaya. In mid-1926
column3: GM approached the British administration in Singapore and requested permission to build an assembly plant in the affluent Tanjong Katong area. However
column4: the local British authorities denied GM's application on grounds that it would 'spoil the amenities of the Katong residential area'. In light of the situation
column5: GM decided to set up their regional assembly plant in the Dutch East Indies instead.In late 1926
column6: a General Motors delegation approached the Dutch administration in Java. GM was granted permission to set up an assembly plant near Batavia
column7: and in February 1927
column8: N.V. General Motors Java Handel Maatschappij (GM Java) was established. The all-new GM Java plant
column9: the colony's first automobile assembly plant
column10: commenced production in May 1927. GM Java exported its produce throughout the Dutch East Indies
column11: British Malaya
column12: French Indochina and Siam.On the onset of World War II
column13: the Dutch East Indies fell to the invading Japanese Army in March 1942. The GM Java plant was taken over by Toyota
column14: and was used to assemble trucks for the military. After the Japanese surrender in 1945
column15: the Dutch failed to regain control of their colony
column16: and the Indonesian War of Independence broke out and dragged on for a further four years.

column2: General Motors revived plans for an assembly plant in Singapore. The new plant would assemble cars and trucks from components imported from GM's subsidiaries in Canada and Britain. Operations would begin in early 1948
column3: and the plant would serve all of GM Java's former export markets
column4: in addition to parts of southern China. However
column5: in June 1948
column6: the local British administration banned imports of American cars into Malaya and Singapore
column7: and GM was once again forced out of Singapore. Following the 1950 Indonesian independence
column8: GM's plant in Java was restructured
column9: and became the Djakarta Branch of the GM Overseas Corporation. However
column10: in April 1956
column11: GM's shareholders liquidated the Djakarta Branch
column12: and General Motors sold their Indonesian plant to P.N. Gaja Motors.

column2: Malaya gained its independence and the Federation of Malaya was formed. Singapore
column3: Sarawak and North Borneo remained British crown colonies. In the late 1950s
column4: the Malayan government began to emphasise industrialisation as a more dependable sector for economic stability and growth. Global tin and natural rubber demand witnessed large slumps and fluctuations throughout the early 20th century
column5: and the mass production of synthetic rubber during World War II also had severe implications on the future sustainability of Malayan rubber exports.The Malayan government initially pursued a policy of Import Substitution Industrialisation (ISI)
column6: in line with most developing countries of that period. ISI develops self-sufficiency through the creation of a strong domestic market
column7: and is primarily state-driven through nationalisation
column8: subsidisation
column9: increased taxation and protectionist trade policies. The earliest Malaysian-made goods produced as a result of the new ISI policy included batteries
column10: tires and paints.

column1: ==== The Federation of Malaysia is formed ====

column2: Malaya
column3: Singapore
column4: Sarawak and North Borneo merged to create the Federation of Malaysia. The merger had granted the latter three states their independence. The new joint Malaysian-Singaporean governments later announced plans to establish an ISI-based national automotive industry
column5: as per the recommendation of advisers from the Colombo Plan. The Malaysian Minister of Commerce and Industry
column6: Lim Swee Aun
column7: would become a key figure in the formation of Malaysia's automotive industry.The 1964 Malaysian automotive policy aimed to accelerate national industrialisation through the local assembly of vehicles and manufacturing of automobile components. The government would issue manufacturing licenses to both foreign and local companies who were interested in setting up automobile assembly plants in any Malaysian state
column8: including Singapore. The government would reduce imports of complete-built up (CBU) vehicles by means of quota regulations and tariffs
column9: and locally assembled (SKD or CKD) vehicles with Malaysian manufactured components would be granted reductions in import duties
column10: making them cheaper and more competitive as a result.

column1: By setting up local assembly plants
column2: the government hoped to create more job opportunities and establish a market for Malaysian-made parts (local content) such as tires
column3: paints
column4: batteries
column5: electrical cables
column6: upholstery and other rubber-based goods. The government hoped that the gradual increase of local content and technology transfer over the next decade or two would eventually bring about cars that are fully 'Made in Malaysia'.By May 1964
column7: nineteen firms
column8: both foreign and local
column9: had responded to the government's call for local assembly and parts production.

column2: Singapore separated from Malaysia amid escalating political tensions
column3: and both governments began to compete for foreign investment. In 1966
column4: ten automobile firms banded together to establish the Motor Vehicle Assemblers Association (MVAA)
column5: and pleaded for a common automotive market between Malaysia and the newly independent Singapore. The MVAA argued that local assembly would prove economically unsustainable if both governments refused to co-operate. The combined markets of Malaysia and Singapore stood at around 33
column6: 000 vehicles a year
column7: with Singapore accounting for 25% of sales.However
column8: political differences dominated and the MVAA common market proposal was refused. The Malaysian government later restricted automobile imports from Singapore and revised its automotive policy
column9: forcing investors to choose between the two countries. The Singaporean government later presented its own automotive policy in 1967. It was largely identical to the original Malaysian policy
column10: with only minor changes to local content definitions. By 1970
column11: both Malaysia and Singapore boasted a roughly equal number of assembly plants. The Singaporean plants were almost entirely backed by British and German companies
column12: while the vast majority of Japanese companies backed Malaysian plants exclusively.The Singaporean automotive industry showed strong initial promise
column13: but was ultimately short lived. Rising costs
column16: limited exports and a small domestic market had made local assembly unsustainable by the mid-1970s. In July 1979
column17: the Singaporean government announced plans to abolish preferential treatment for all local assemblers by the end of 1980. By July 1980
column18: all major car assembly plants in Singapore had shut down.

column1: ==== The automotive industry in Malaysia begins ====

column2: the Malaysian government approved applications for six automobile assembly plants.
Western car companies dominated the Malayan automobile market. But in the late 1950s
column3: Japanese car companies rose to challenge the status quo. The tides shifted dramatically over the course of the 1960s
column4: and by the end of the 1970s
column5: Japanese car companies had become the dominant players in the Malaysian market.The first Japanese cars arrived in Malaysia during the mid 1950s. Initially
column6: the Japanese cars proved unpopular
column7: and were perceived as inferior to their Western counterparts. The lightness and thin construction of the early Japanese cars were often criticised
column8: and popularised the derogatory term 'Milo tin' in the 1960s. In addition to the quality concerns
column9: anti-Japanese sentiment was still strong in 1950s and 1960s Malaysia
column10: owing to bitter memories from the Japanese occupation several years prior.However
column11: the Japanese cars continued to improve and gained a reputation for quality
column12: reliability
column13: high fuel efficiency and value for money. The Japanese cars were also on average cheaper than their more premium Western counterparts. Only a handful of Western companies such as Ford
column14: Morris and Fiat were able to match the affordability of the Japanese cars.

column1: Datsun (later Nissan) lead the rise of Japanese cars in Malaysia. The greatest threat to Datsun's dominance came from another Japanese brand
column2: Toyota. Both Toyota and Datsun battled fiercely for pole position in the Malaysian market
column3: at times only fractions apart in total market share. Other Japanese car companies such as Mazda
column4: Colt (later Mitsubishi) and Honda had also become well-established in Malaysia by the 1970s.

column1: Prices of new cars in Malaysia had inflated significantly through the 1970s
column2: with most if not all locally assembled CKD models generally costing more to produce than an equivalent CBU import.The inflation of new car prices was attributed to several factors
column3: including low efficiency and inadequate economies of scale among the parts manufacturers and assembly plants
column4: the government's mandatory CKD deletion policy
column5: high import and excise taxes for the CKD models
column6: and various others. Additionally
column7: the automotive industry in Malaysia was held back by a small domestic market
column8: and manufacturers primarily served domestic demand and did not emphasise exports
column9: thus limiting the growth and competitiveness of the industry as a whole.

column2: the government concluded that direct involvement was necessary to reverse losses and spur future industrial growth. The National Car Project was drafted in the early 80s with the objective of accelerating technology transfer
column3: increasing and rationalising local content
column4: and involving more bumiputera entrepreneurs in the then largely ethnic Chinese dominated Malaysian automotive industry. The National Car Project would lead to the founding of Perusahaan Otomobil Nasional Sdn. Bhd. (Proton) in May 1983
column5: and the launch of the Proton Saga in July 1985.

column1: According to the Ministry of Transport
column2: the active passenger car population in Malaysia stood at 11 million units in 2014
column3: with 10 passenger cars for every 27 citizens. An independent study estimated that the population stood at around 8.2 million units in 2014
column4: after factoring in variables such as scrapped and permanently disabled passenger cars.

column1: National car company Proton currently operates three manufacturing plants in Malaysia
column2: with a combined maximum annual capacity of 360
column3: 000 units. The original Proton plant in Shah Alam was built in 1985
column4: and was later complemented by the smaller MVF plant in 2000. The third Proton factory near Tanjung Malim commenced operations in 2004
column5: and was built as part of the Proton City project. Perusahaan Otomobil Nasional (PONSB) handles operations at both plants in Shah Alam
column6: while Proton Tanjung Malim (PTMSB) operates the plant at Proton City.

column1: Proton's first plant commenced operations in mid-1985
column2: with the first unit being a Proton Saga 1.3L saloon. Initially
column3: Proton had assembled the Saga with complete-knock down (CKD) kits
column4: engines and components which were imported from Mitsubishi's facilities in Japan. Local content in the 1985 Proton Saga stood at 18%
column5: with just 13 local components. By mid-1989
column6: local content had risen to 69%
column7: with over 453 Proton-manufactured components and a further 356 locally-sourced parts from 56 local vendors. In June 1989
column8: Proton commenced engine assembly at their dedicated Engine and Transmission Factory. The Proton plant became a symbol of national industrialisation
column9: and was subsequently commemorated on the RM100 banknote in 1998.

column1: Construction of the Medium Volume Factory (MVF) was completed in 2000. The MVF plant was built adjacent to the original Proton factory
column2: and produced the Proton Waja upon its debut. The MVF plant was built at a cost of RM400 million
column3: and accommodated modern assembly practices like modular assembly and Automatic Line Control (ALC).Construction of an all-new Proton factory commenced in 1996 near Tanjung Malim
column4: in anticipation of increasing sales of Proton cars in the near future. However
column5: its construction was deferred in late 1997 as a result of the Asian financial crisis. Construction resumed in January 2001
column6: and was completed in 2003
column7: and the plant's first Proton GENâ€¢2 models rolled-off the production line in early 2004. Proton's Tanjung Malim complex is five times larger than their Shah Alam complex
column8: and was built at a cost of RM1.8 billion. At its debut in 2004
column9: the Tanjung Malim plant employed 2
column10: 000 workers
column11: featured 180 robots
column12: and had a 60% automation rate. It was billed as the most advanced automobile factory in the Asia-Pacific region
column13: outside Japan and Korea.Proton was originally owned in majority by HICOM with minority stakes being held by Mitsubishi Group members. By 2005
column14: Mitsubishi had divested their stake in Proton to Khazanah Nasional
column16: Proton was fully acquired by DRB-HICOM. In 2017
column17: DRB-HICOM sold a 49.9% stake in Proton to Geely.

column1: Market sales leader Perodua currently operates two manufacturing plants in Malaysia
column2: with a combined maximum annual capacity of 350
column3: 000 units. The first Perodua plant in Serendah commenced operations in 1994
column4: and was later complemented by a larger adjacent factory in 2014. Perodua Manufacturing (PMSB) handles operations at the older plant
column5: while Perodua Global Manufacturing (PGMSB) operates the newly built factory.

column1: Perodua's first plant commenced operations in July 1994
column2: with the first unit being a Perodua Kancil 660cc. Like Proton
column3: Perodua benefited from Japanese technology transfer in its early stages of development. Perodua's products are based on Daihatsu-engineered platforms and engines
column4: and Daihatsu has led Perodua's manufacturing operations since 2001. Perodua had previously assembled the first generation Toyota Avanza under contract
column5: and the company currently produces models with Daihatsu badging for export to the Indonesian market.

column2: Perodua announced plans for an all-new factory
column3: to be built adjacent to their original plant in Serendah. Construction commenced in March 2013
column4: and completed in late 2014
column5: and the plant's first Perodua Axia models rolled-off the production line in August 2014. The all-new Perodua plant was built at a cost of RM1.3 billion
column6: and is modelled after Daihatsu Motor Kyushu (DKC) Nakatsu Plant 2 in Japan. Perodua aims to emulate DKC's low defects per unit (DPU) rate and environmentally friendly practices.In May 2014
column7: Perodua and Daihatsu revealed plans for an all-new RM600 million engine manufacturing plant
column8: to be built in Sendayan. Construction commenced in October 2014
column9: and operations commenced in May 2016. The new engine plant is handled by Daihatsu Perodua Engine Manufacturing (DPEM)
column10: and currently produces the 1.3-litre
column11: 1NR-VE and 1.5-litre
column12: 2NR-FE engines for the Perodua Bezza and Malaysian-market Toyota Vios. Additionally
column13: Perodua has a 10% stake in the Akashi Kikai (AKIM) transmission manufacturing plant
column14: also in Sendayan. The all-new AKIM plant commenced operations in March 2014
column15: and currently supplies manual and automatic gearboxes for Perodua's models.

column1: Tan Chong Motor Holdings (TCMH) currently operates two manufacturing plants in Malaysia
column2: with a combined maximum annual capacity of 100
column3: 000 units. Tan Chong Motor Assemblies (TCMA)
column4: a subsidiary of TCMH
column5: handles all plant operations. TCMA assembles a large variety of foreign badged models from imported complete knock down (CKD) kits. The original TCMA plant in Segambut was built in 1976
column6: and currently assembles Subaru
column7: Mitsubishi and Renault models
column8: in addition to various commercial vehicles. The second TCMA plant in Serendah commenced operations in 2007
column9: and assembles Nissan models exclusively.

column1: Tan Chong Motor has been an active player in the Malaysian automotive industry since 1957. The company sold fully imported Datsun vehicles in its early years of business
column2: but government initiatives prompted Tan Chong Motor to offer their first locally assembled Datsun models from mid-1968. Sales of Datsun cars grew significantly in the 1960s
column3: and in 1970
column4: Datsun became the best-selling brand of car in the Malaysian market. In mid-2003
column5: Tan Chong Motor adopted the Renault brand in line with the Renaultâ€“Nissan Alliance.

column1: Tan Chong Motor constructed their own assembly plant at Segambut in 1976. The new TCMA plant was modelled after the Nissan Zama complex
column2: and was the nation's first to use electro-dipping (ED) technology for its painting process. Nissan Japan regarded the TCMA plant as the third best foreign Nissan assembly plant in the world. The TCMA plant also became the nation's first to feature an engine assembly line in December 1988. TCMA had also pioneered women's rights in the traditionally male dominated automotive industry
column3: with females accounting for 44% of their assembly workforce in 1989.

column1: The bulk of TCMA Segambut production historically consisted of Datsun/Nissan vehicles
column2: but the plant has also carried out contract assembly for Subaru
column3: Volkswagen
column4: Audi
column5: Peugeot and Renault models in the past. A small number of Malaysian-assembled Mercedes-Benz models were also sent to TCMA for painting. The TCMA Segambut plant has mainly catered to domestic consumption
column6: and only a small number of vehicles were exported. Presently
column7: both Subaru XV and Forester models assembled by TCMA Segambut are exported to Thailand and Indonesia
column8: with export volume exceeding domestic consumption.Construction for an all-new TCMA assembly plant at Serendah commenced in February 2006. The new plant complements the existing Segambut facility
column9: and incorporate more advanced manufacturing standards under the Nissan Production Way (NPW). The Nissan Latio became the first model to roll off the new TCMA Serendah plant in 2007. Tan Chong Motor/Nissan is one of only two domestic-foreign joint venture companies to simultaneously operate two automobile assembly plants in Malaysia.

column1: Honda Malaysia (HM) currently operates an assembly plant in Pegoh
column2: with a combined maximum annual capacity of 100
column3: 000 units. HM assembles Honda passenger cars from imported complete knock down (CKD) kits. Honda Malaysia's shareholders include the Honda Motor Company (51%)
column4: DRB-HICOM (34%) and Oriental Holdings (15%).

column1: Honda Malaysia was established in July 2000 as DRB-Oriental-Honda (DOH)
column2: a three-way joint venture between Honda
column3: DRB-HICOM and Oriental. DOH was established to handle assembly
column4: distribution and sales of Honda passenger cars in Malaysia. DRB-Oriental-Honda changed its name to Honda Malaysia (HM) in September 2002. Prior to the advent of Honda Malaysia
column5: Honda operations in Malaysia were handled by Oriental Holdings and their associates
column6: which collectively held the franchise rights for both Honda passenger cars and motorcycles in Malaysia. Honda passenger cars were assembled at the Oriental Assemblers plant in Tampoi
column7: Johor
column8: while Honda motorcycles were built at the Boon Siew Honda Assembly plant in Butterworth
column9: Penang. Both plants had produced Honda models since 1969.

column2: Honda's principles in Japan had sought to become more directly involved in the Malaysian market. The decision was made in anticipation of the impending AFTA implementation in the early 2000s
column3: a period in which many foreign car companies had increased their market presence in Malaysia. Additionally
column4: various complications between Honda and the Oriental Group had also catalysed Honda's decision to establish a direct presence in the Malaysian market.Under the DRB-Oriental-Honda joint venture
column5: Oriental Holdings would concentrate on the marketing and sales of Honda vehicles
column6: while Honda would handle assembly operations. The DOH joint venture only encompassed Honda passenger vehicles
column7: while Honda motorcycle operations remained unchanged. Additionally
column8: Honda had decided on the construction of an all-new assembly plant in Pegoh
column9: Malacca
column10: which would take over Honda assembly operations from Oriental Assemblers. Construction of the new plant commenced in August 2001
column11: and was completed in November 2002. The Pegoh plant was built at the cost of RM180 million
column12: with an initial capacity of 20
column13: 000 units annually. The earliest second generation Honda CR-V models rolled out of the Pegoh plant in December 2002. In addition to vehicle assembly
column14: the Pegoh plant also manufactures constant velocity joints for both domestic and export markets. The plant produced its 100

column2: Honda Malaysia established a second vehicle assembly line at the Pegoh plant. The second line was built at the cost of RM382 million
column3: and doubled annual production capacity from 50
column5: 000 units annually. Honda Malaysia's second line also became the first outside Japan to feature Honda's Smart Welding Machine technology.

column2: sales and market share grew significantly in the 2010s. In 2015
column3: Honda surpassed arch-rival Toyota as the best-selling foreign-badged car company in Malaysia. The following year
column4: Honda surpassed Proton to place second overall in the Malaysian market. Honda Malaysia currently assembles seven different models
column5: the highest among any Japanese-badged car company in Malaysia. HM also assembles hybrid variants of the Jazz and City respectively.

column1: Inokom Corporation operates an assembly plant in Kulim with a combined maximum annual capacity of 30
column2: 000 units. Inokom is the licensed contract assembler for Hyundai
column3: BMW and Mazda passenger vehicles in Malaysia. Inokom's shareholders include Sime Darby Motors (51%)
column4: Sime Darby Hyundai (5%)
column5: Hyundai Motor Company (15%) and Berjaya Auto (29%).

column1: Inokom was established in 1992 as one of two national commercial vehicle companies. In its early years of business
column2: Inokom produced rebadged Renault and Hyundai commercial vehicles exclusively. The company's first product
column3: the Inokom Permas debuted in 1998. The Permas is based on the first generation Renault Traffic and was produced in various configurations at Inokom's new plant in Kulim
column4: Kedah. In 2000
column5: Inokom launched its second product
column6: the Lorimas
column7: a license-built Hyundai Porter.In 2002
column8: Inokom ventured into non-commercial vehicle production with the launch of the Hyundai-based Inokom Atos. In 2004
column9: Sime Darby acquired a 51% stake in Inokom
column10: and by the 2010s
column11: all Hyundai assembly operations in Malaysia were centralised at the Inokom plant. Prior to the consolidation
column12: Hyundai models were assembled at two separate plants
column13: namely the Inokom plant in Kulim and the Oriental Assemblers plant in Tampoi.

column1: Inokom's acquisition by Sime Darby also led to the assembly of BMW and Land Rover models at the Inokom plant in 2008. BMW and Land Rover vehicles were previously assembled at the Associated Motor Industries plant in Shah Alam. In 2018
column2: local assembly of BMW engines commenced at a new engine assembly plant
column3: while exports of Inokom-built BMWs commenced in 2019.Mazda assembly at Inokom commenced in 2011 under a separate initiative by the Berjaya Group. Inokom has also carried out contract assembly for Dongfeng
column4: Jinbei and Ford commercial vehicles.

column1: Volvo Car Manufacturing Malaysia (VCMM) operates an assembly plant in Shah Alam with an annual capacity of 10
column2: 000 units. VCMM assembles Volvo passenger cars for both domestic and export markets. Volvo Car Manufacturing Malaysia is a wholly owned subsidiary of Sweden-based Volvo Car Corporation. The 50-year-old VCMM plant is the oldest automobile assembly plant in Malaysia
column3: and is widely credited as one of the pioneers of the Malaysian automotive industry.

column1: The VCMM plant was established as Swedish Motor Assemblies (SMA) in September 1966 through a joint venture between AB Volvo and the Federal Auto Company Sdn. Bhd. Swedish Motor Assemblies was established in response to a government-proposed initiative to the set up an automotive industry in Malaysia. Construction of the SMA plant commenced in March 1967
column2: and was completed in October 1967. The first Volvo 144 units rolled-off the assembly line in November 1967. By 1971
column3: SMA had commenced assembly of Volvo trucks and buses.Throughout its history
column4: Swedish Motor Assemblies had assembled a wide variety of Volvo passenger and commercial vehicles. SMA had also conducted contract assembly operations for various car companies
column5: including Datsun
column6: Alfa Romeo
column7: Daihatsu
column8: Subaru
column9: Suzuki
column10: Renault
column11: Land Rover
column12: Mazda and Perodua among others. At times
column13: SMA's production volume for non-Volvo cars vastly exceeded that of Volvo-badged cars.However
column15: contract assembly operations at the SMA plant had scaled down
column16: as SMA consolidated operations to focus on Volvo production exclusively. By 2013
column17: Swedish Motor Assemblies had changed its name to Volvo Car Manufacturing Malaysia
column18: to better reflect its current identity.The SMA plant historically catered to the Malaysian market
column19: with intermittent low volume exports to neighbouring countries. In 2016
column20: VCMM announced plans to facilitate exports to regional left-hand drive markets
column22: export demand had outpaced domestic sales. VCMM currently exports right-hand drive models to Thailand and Indonesia
column23: and left-hand drive units to Taiwan

column1: Assembly Services Sdn. Bhd. (ASSB) currently operates two assembly plants with a combined annual capacity of 150
column2: 000 units. The original ASSB Shah Alam plant was built in 1968
column3: and was later complemented by the all-new ASSB Bukit Raja plant in 2019. ASSB assembles Toyota passenger and commercial vehicles from imported complete knock down (CKD) kits. Assembly Services is a wholly owned subsidiary of UMW Toyota Motor Sdn. Bhd. (UMWT)
column4: which is in turn a subsidiary of UMW Holdings (51%)
column5: Toyota Motor Corporation (39%) and Toyota Tsusho Corporation (10%). Assembly Services was established in 1967 as Champion Motors (CM)
column6: then a subsidiary of the Inchcape group. Champion Motors was renamed Assembly Services in 1975
column7: prior to its acquisition by UMW and Toyota in 1982. The original ASSB plant is among the oldest automobile assembly plants in Malaysia
column8: and one of the few to surpass the 1 million cumulative production milestone.Toyota's history in Malaysia can be traced back to the mid 1940s. During the Japanese occupation of Malaya
column9: Toyoda (as Toyota was then known) military trucks were among those produced at the occupied Ford Malaya plant in Singapore. After the war
column10: Toyota returned to Malaysia in the late 1950s
column11: and the sales and reputation of Toyota vehicles grew over course of the 1960s. However
column12: the Toyota brand franchise in Malaysia was constantly beset with obstacles and problems
column13: and the franchise would change hands multiple times before settling with its current owner

column1: Toyota's first appointed Malaysian distributor was the Asia Motor Company
column2: founded by the Ph'ng family from Penang. Asia Motor imported the Toyota Land Cruiser (FJ25) into Malaya in August 1957
column3: as well as the Toyota Truck (FA70) the following year. However
column4: Asia Motor's contract soon expired
column5: and in September 1960
column6: Toyota signed a new distributor agreement with Kah Motor
column7: a wholly owned subsidiary of Penang-based Oriental Holdings
column8: chaired by Loh Boon Siew. Kah Motor imported Toyota and Toyopet passenger cars such as the Tiara and Publica for sale in Malaya and Singapore. In December 1963
column9: Kah Motor and Toyota announced plans for a Toyota assembly plant in Butterworth
column10: in response to the Malaysian government's proposal to set up a domestic automotive industry.

column2: various complications occurred in the following years
column3: and in 1967
column4: Toyota signed a separate distributor agreement with Borneo Motors
column5: a subsidiary of London-based Inchcape. That same year
column6: Borneo Motors' sister company
column7: Motor Investments (MIB) commenced construction of the Champion Motors (CM) assembly plant in Shah Alam. In February 1968
column8: the first Malaysian-assembled Toyota models rolled out of the Champion Motors plant. In addition to Toyota models
column9: Champion Motors also assembled Volkswagen
column10: Vauxhall
column11: Chevrolet and Mercedes-Benz models in its initial years of operations. Although not an official Toyota plant
column12: Champion Motors benefited significantly from Japanese technology transfer by adopting the Toyota Production System. By the 1970s
column13: Toyota models had accounted for the largest share of Champion Motors' production. In July 1975
column14: Champion Motors was renamed Assembly Services (ASSB). Apart from Borneo Motors
column15: Toyota had also granted the franchise rights for Toyota commercial vehicles (Hilux and Land Cruiser) to other Malaysian companies such as Emastorin Motor and Sarin Motor
column16: the latter of which oversaw Land Cruiser assembly at the Sarawak Motor Industries (SMI) plant for the East Malaysian market.

column2: various complications had brought about yet another franchise transition. In 1981
column3: negotiations between Toyota and United Motor Works (UMW)
column4: led by Eric Chia culminated in UMW's appointment as the new Toyota franchise holder in Malaysia. The following year
column5: UMW
column6: through its subsidiary Sejati Motor acquired the Assembly Services plant and Borneo Motors network from Inchcape. By 1983
column7: Toyota operations in both West and East Malaysia were unified
column8: and in 1987
column9: Sejati Motor was renamed UMW Toyota Motor (UMWT). The UMW group has held the Toyota franchise ever since.

column1: The Assembly Services plant is further supplemented by sister companies of UMW Toyota
column2: most notably Automotive Industries (AISB) and Toyota Boshoku UMW (TBU) which manufacture exhaust systems and interior components respectively. UMW Toyota subsidiaries also supply components to non-Toyota plants in Malaysia and abroad. Additionally
column3: Toyota is the sole foreign car company to carry out body panel stamping operations for select Malaysian-built models through its subsidiary
column4: Toyota Auto Body Malaysia (TABM). In 2016
column5: UMW and Toyota announced plans for a second Toyota assembly plant in Bukit Raja
column6: with a capital investment of RM2 billion. Construction of the second plant was completed in late 2018
column7: and operations commenced in January 2019 with the debut of the revised third generation Vios.

column1: Go Automobile Manufacturing Sdn. Bhd. (GAM) currently operates an assembly plant in Gurun with an annual capacity of 25
column2: 000 units. GAM assembles Haval and Great Wall Motors (GWM) vehicles for both domestic and export markets. Go Automobile Manufacturing is a subsidiary of Malaysia-based Go Auto Group of Companies. Go Auto is the appointed distributor
column3: assembler and exporter of Haval and Great Wall Motors vehicles for the ASEAN region.

column1: The Go Auto plant was established in the late 2000s by MAZS Sdn. Bhd.
column2: a subsidiary of Green Oranges Sdn. Bhd. (GOSB). In mid 2011
column3: Green Oranges imported the first Great Wall vehicles into Malaysia
column4: and local assembly operations commenced later that year. In April 2014
column5: Go Auto became the first company to be awarded with an Energy Efficient Vehicle (EEV) manufacturing license from MITI. The Green Oranges plant was subsequently developed into Go Automobile Manufacturing
column6: and further investments into a second
column7: adjacent facility increased production capacity from 10
column8: 000 units annually to 25
column9: 000 units by 2015. The Go Auto plant is located across the street from the Naza Automotive Manufacturing plant.

column1: The Go Auto plant employs a unique 'factory-in-factory' or 'Tier 0' approach
column2: in which component suppliers or vendors are invited to directly participate in automobile assembly by setting up smaller factories within the larger plant itself. Each vendor concentrates and specialises on a specific section of the assembly line
column3: while Go Auto supervises the overall assembly process. All vendors co-ordinate and co-operate with each other to solve problems and achieve high quality control standards. The 'Tier 0' system aims to develop and enhance local vendor capabilities.In addition to Great Wall and Haval vehicles
column4: Go Auto has also carried out contract assembly for Hafei
column5: BAIC
column6: Jinbei and Dongfeng commercial vehicles in recent years. Go Auto has exported Haval SUVs to Thailand
column7: Brunei
column8: Indonesia and Cambodia. The company has expressed plans to widen exports to additional ASEAN countries in the near future.

column1: HICOM Automotive Manufacturers (Malaysia) Sdn. Bhd. (HA) currently operates two main assembly plants in Pekan
column2: which collectively encompass several smaller sub-plants and facilities. HA is part of the DRB-HICOM Pekan automotive complex
column3: which is among the nation's largest automobile production hubs. The entire automotive complex is divided by a section of the Federal Route 3 highway
column4: which separates HA Plant 1 to the West
column5: from HA Plant 2 to the East. Plant 1 hosts the Volkswagen Pekan Plant (VPP)
column6: which produces Volkswagen passenger vehicles
column7: and the Suzuki Malaysia Automobile plant
column8: which is currently idle. Plant 2 hosts the Mercedes-Benz Malaysia (MBM) plant
column9: which produces Mercedes-Benz passenger and commercial vehicles
column10: in addition to Mitsubishi Fuso commercial vehicles. All three sub-plants assemble vehicles from imported knock down kits. Additionally
column11: the DRB-HICOM Defence Technologies (DefTech) facility and Isuzu HICOM Malaysia (IHM) plant are both located in close proximity to Plant 1 and 2. DefTech and IHM are not part of HICOM Automotive Manufacturers (Malaysia)
column12: but DefTech is nonetheless a subsidiary of DRB-HICOM
column13: while IHM is a 51:49 joint venture between Isuzu and HICOM. The Pekan automotive complex has produced a diverse variety of vehicles over the course of its history
column14: with models from over 20 different car companies

column1: HICOM Automotive Manufacturers (Malaysia) traces its origins to the mid 1970s
column2: when the TATAB Industries Assembly Plant (TIAP) was established under a 70:30 joint venture between Pahang-based TAB group and Tata of India. The development of the TIAP plant was partially funded by the Pahang royal family
column3: and upon its completion in 1976
column4: it became the first automobile assembly plant in the East Coast region. In the late 1970s and early 1980s
column5: TIAP produced Tata commercial vehicles
column6: but in 1983
column7: the Master Carriage group
column8: an affiliate company of Diversified Resources Berhad (DRB) bought the TIAP facility
column9: and renamed it Automotive Manufacturers (Malaysia) Sdn. Bhd. (AMM). Over the course of the mid 1980s and early 1990s
column10: the AMM plant would take on contract assembly for Isuzu
column11: Suzuki and Mitsubishi commercial vehicles
column12: as well as CitroÃ«n passenger vehicles.By late 1994
column13: the AMM complex had grown to accommodate 8 separate assembly lines. In July 1995
column14: AMM commenced operations at a second assembly plant
column16: on the eastern bank of the Federal Route 3 highway at the Peramu Jaya industrial estate. AMM 2 was tasked with the assembly of commercial vehicles exclusively
column17: while the original plant on the western bank
column19: would specialise in passenger car assembly. The combined annual production capacity of the AMM complex stood at around 80

column2: AMM became one of two plants to participate in the National Commercial Vehicle (NCV) project
column3: when HICOM Commercial Vehicles was established in January 1994 under a 40:40:20 joint venture between DRB
column4: HICOM and Isuzu. By 1996
column5: HICOM Commercial Vehicles had been renamed Malaysian Truck & Bus (MTB)
column6: while DRB and HICOM had merged. MTB had acquired the AMM 2 plant for the NCV project
column7: and plans for a HICOM-badged
column8: Isuzu-based
column9: AMM-built truck were unveiled. In July 1997
column10: the HICOM Perkasa was launched as the first product from the MTB joint venture. The Perkasa is based on the fifth-generation Isuzu Elf
column11: and it was produced in both narrow-cab
column12: short wheelbase and wide-cab
column13: long wheelbase configurations. Isuzu vehicles have also formed the basis for other HICOM-badged vehicles
column14: most notably the DefTech-built HICOM Handalan series. In 2007
column15: Isuzu acquired a 51% majority stake in MTB
column16: and the company was subsequently renamed Isuzu HICOM Malaysia.

column1: Aside from the joint venture with Isuzu
column2: AMM had also hosted a second concurrent partnership with national car company Proton. In June 1994
column3: Usahasama Proton-DRB (USPD) was established under 51:30:19 joint venture between DRB
column4: Proton and Erat Bakti. USPD was established to market niche or non-mainstream Proton models
column5: as a complement to HICOM-directed Edaran Otomobil Nasional (EON)
column6: which concentrated on mainstream Proton models. By November 1994
column7: production of the Proton Satria had commenced on a dedicated assembly line at the AMM complex. By 1996
column8: AMM had been granted an export certificate from Britain's Vehicle Certification Agency
column9: and through its alliance with Proton
column10: AMM became one of the few domestic plants to have ever exported cars to the United Kingdom.

column2: DRB's relationship with Citroen and Proton had converged into a tripartite joint venture by way of a Proton-badged
column3: Citroen-based
column4: AMM-built model. The first and only model from the joint venture
column5: the Proton Tiara
column6: was launched in April 1996. Further plans were made for a second
column7: Saxo-based model
column8: and DRB had invested in additional plant capacity to accommodate future exports. However
column9: the three-way joint venture suffered multiple complications and setbacks
column10: including the loss of then HICOM chairman Yahaya Ahmad in 1997
column11: and the subsequent Asian financial crisis. Production of the Tiara ceased in late 1999
column12: but AMM continued to produce other Mitsubishi-based
column13: Proton-badged vehicles up to the mid 2000s. By late 2000
column15: and the company was subsequently renamed Proton Edar.

column2: AMM had taken on contract assembly for additional companies. In October 2001
column3: AMM entered into a contract assembly agreement with Naza
column4: the appointed Kia Motors franchise holder in Malaysia. Naza had sought to temporarily utilise AMM's facilities while construction of their own plant in Gurun took place. Under the agreement with Naza
column5: the AMM plant produced the Kia Spectra
column6: Pregio and K2700
column7: as well as Naza-badged vehicles such as the Ria and Sutera up to the mid 2000s. By the 2010s
column8: assembly of Kia and Naza vehicles had been fully relocated to the Naza Automotive Manufacturing plant. The AMM plant had also assembled SsangYong vehicles under another contract agreement with Competitive Supreme (CSSB).By the mid 2000s
column9: the Pekan automotive complex had taken on assembly of Mercedes-Benz vehicles through a joint venture between DaimlerChrysler Malaysia (DCM) and Malaysian Truck & Bus (MTB). DaimlerChrysler Malaysia was a 51:49 joint venture between DaimlerChrysler AG
column10: which owned Mercedes-Benz
column11: and Cycle & Carriage Bintang (CCB)
column12: the long-standing Mercedes-Benz franchise holder in Malaysia. Prior to the MTB and DCM joint venture
column13: Mercedes-Benz vehicles were assembled concurrently at two different plants
column14: namely Asia Automobile Industries in Petaling Jaya and Oriental Assemblers in Tampoi. To better coordinate logistics and quality control
column15: Mercedes-Benz had sought to consolidate their Malaysian assembly operations at a single plant. Thus
column17: Mercedes-Benz approached MTB through its subsidiary
column19: and plans were made to shift Malaysian assembly of future Mercedes-Benz vehicles to the MTB plant. DCM did not acquire an equity stake in MTB
column20: but it was nonetheless allowed to operate autonomously
column21: as Mercedes-Benz vehicles would be assembled on dedicated assembly lines
column22: and only the paint shops would be shared with other companies at MTB and AMM.

column1: The first Mercedes-Benz cars from the DCM and MTB joint venture rolled off the assembly line in early 2005. By 2007
column2: Mercedes-Benz passenger models from the C
column3: E and S-Class nameplates were being assembled on three separate assembly lines. Assembly of Mercedes-Benz commercial models and Mitsubishi Fuso vehicles also took place at an adjacent facility. In January 2008
column4: DaimlerChrysler Malaysia was renamed Mercedes-Benz Malaysia
column5: following the Mercedes-Benz and Chrysler demerger. Since 2004
column6: Mercedes-Benz has invested over RM300 million in their Pekan operations. The Mercedes-Benz Malaysia plant has since produced nine different passenger models from the C-Class (W203
column7: W204 and W205)
column8: E-Class (W211
column9: W212 and W213)
column10: S-Class (V221 and V222)
column11: and GLC-Class (X253) nameplates respectively. Since 2013
column12: MBM has also produced hybrid and plug-in hybrid models
column13: which benefit from extensive tax rebates under the government's EEV incentive. Production
column14: sales and market share of Mercedes-Benz vehicles grew significantly in the 2010s
column15: and cumulative volume has since surpassed 100
column17: MBM commenced assembly of left-hand drive C-Class for export to the Philippines.

column1: Around the time when MTB secured their contract assembly agreement with Mercedes-Benz
column2: AMM had also received a separate contract deal for the assembly of Suzuki passenger cars when DRB-HICOM was awarded the Suzuki franchise for the Malaysian market. DRB-HICOM established Suzuki Malaysia Automobile (SMA) in December 2004
column3: and plans were made to assemble the Suzuki Swift on a dedicated assembly line at the Pekan complex. Although low volumes were anticipated
column4: Suzuki invested RM20 million to establish a robotic welding line to ensure quality control and efficiency. The first Swift units from Suzuki Malaysia Automobile were produced in June 2007.In early 2008
column5: Suzuki Malaysia Automobile became a three-way 40:40:20 joint venture between DRB-HICOM
column6: Suzuki and Itochu
column7: when the latter two acquired stakes in the operation. In November 2008
column8: AMM was renamed HICOM Automotive Manufacturers (Malaysia) Sdn. Bhd. (HAMM). Local assembly of the next generation Swift commenced in May 2013. In June 2015
column9: Suzuki and Proton entered into a partnership
column10: in which selected Suzuki models would be rebadged and produced by Proton for the Malaysian market. To prevent sales overlapping between Proton and Suzuki models
column11: Suzuki voluntarily withdrew from the Malaysian market
column12: and local assembly
column13: imports and sales of Suzuki-badged cars ceased by 2016. Suzuki's local assembly operations in Malaysia have since transitioned to Proton's Tanjung Malim plant by way of the Ertiga MPV.

column2: HAMM had commenced contract assembly of Volkswagen passenger vehicles as part of an agreement with DRB-HICOM and Volkswagen. Prior to the agreement with DRB-HICOM
column3: Volkswagen had initially pursued a partnership with Proton. Volkswagen had sought to utilise Proton's new Tanjung Malim plant as their manufacturing hub in ASEAN
column4: and had also planned to collaborate with Proton on the development of ASEAN-market models. Two rounds of discussions between Proton and Volkswagen took place between 2004 and 2007
column5: but various complications and political intervention prevented further developments between the two companies. After the discussions with Proton ended inconclusively
column6: Volkswagen signed a contract assembly agreement with DRB-HICOM instead.

column1: The Volkswagen Pekan Plant (VPP) was set up within the Pekan complex
column2: and the first VPP-built Volkswagen cars rolled off the assembly line in March 2012. VPP has since produced six different Volkswagen models from the Passat
column3: Polo
column4: Vento
column5: Jetta and Tiguan nameplates. VPP is also one of only two Malaysian plants to have used laser welding in the assembly process. The knock down kits and engines are shipped in from Volkswagen's plants in Germany
column6: Mexico
column7: India and South Africa. In late 2014
column8: Volkswagen expressed intentions to export their Malaysian-built models to ASEAN markets
column9: but various complications have since throttled Volkswagen's ASEAN expansion plans.In late 2016
column10: HICOM Automotive Manufacturers (Malaysia) changed its abbreviation to HA
column11: from HAMM previously. In July 2017
column12: HA built a new paint shop at the cost of RM230 million. The new paint shop is highly automated
column13: and is the nation's first to feature a 360-degree rotating electro-dipping (ED) process
column14: which is more efficient than conventional vertical ED systems. Mercedes-Benz Malaysia's models are currently painted at the new paint shop.

column1: The New National Car Project (NNCP) is the given name of an industrial initiative tasked with the development of a new Malaysian automobile company. The NNCP aims to create the third national car company after Proton and Perodua. The NNCP approach will not follow the government-funded
column2: foreign technology-dependent formula used to create Proton and Perodua
column3: but will instead be funded by domestic private sector institutions with primarily local talent and technologies. Nonetheless
column4: there are plans to collaborate with foreign companies in the short term.

column2: the main proponent of the third national car
column3: justifies the need for its existence as part of a long-term vision for Malaysia to develop self-sufficiency with high-tech industries and a highly-skilled labour force. Mahathir argues that a competitive automotive industry is a necessary pre-requisite for Malaysia to be considered a developed nation. Additionally
column4: the sale of Proton to China-based Geely also contributed to the NNCP cause. Mahathir had championed Proton since its inception
column5: and strongly objected to any foreign buyout of Proton. The NNCP is often cited as an indirect replacement to Proton
column6: which Mahathir no longer regards as a truly Malaysian car company.

column2: the Malaysian Industry-Government Group for High Technology (MIGHT)
column3: an agency under the Prime Minister's Department tasked to oversee the New National Car Project
column4: announced that several companies have been shortlisted
column5: including SilTerra
column6: a Kulim-based semiconductor manufacturer
column7: and Cyberjaya-based Composites Technology Research Malaysia (CTRM)
column8: a composite component manufacturer. SilTerra is a wholly owned subsidiary of Khazanah Nasional
column9: while CTRM is a unit of DRB-HICOM. Both companies are government linked
column10: but the government and Mahathir Mohamad have repeatedly promised that no public funds would be used to fund the NNCP.Additionally
column11: MIGHT has unveiled that the NNCP will include semi-autonomous technology
column12: and be built on a modular platform. Both hybrid and battery electric powertrains are also under consideration. To keep startup costs low and to shorten the overall launch frame
column13: the NNCP vehicles may be produced at an existing automobile plant. The NNCP has a targeted 2020 launch
column14: with plans for ASEAN exports in the near future.In August 2019
column15: the Ministry of International Trade and Industry shortlisted Cyberjaya-based DreamEdge as the company which will spearhead the NNCP
column16: with technical assistance from Daihatsu. MITI reiterated that the NNCP will be privately-funded and domestically owned. The first NNCP product
column17: reportedly a plus-sized B-segment sedan with a standard ICE or hybrid powertrain
column19: it has since been hinted that Perodua may also become involved in the NNCP due to its pre-existing joint-venture with Daihatsu. Later
column20: it was announced that the NNCP launch would be delayed to early 2022
column21: while overall investment costs are estimated to reach RM1 billion.
